utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Thanks for following that story. Up next, we have some major breaking creepy porn lawyer news. It almost pains us to bring it to you. But this time, it's worth it. Stay tuned for that

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well normally we'd call this a Fox News Alert. But tonight, we want to be a little more direct. It's really a creepy porn lawyer alert. A federal judge has dismissed a defamation lawsuit that Stormy Daniels filed against President Trump. Not only that, the judge says that Trump is entitled to receive attorney's fees. That means, of course, that the creepy porn lawyer may have to cut the President, his self-described nemesis, a check. But don't get your hopes up too far, the check would probably bounce. The creepy porn lawyer may realize that too. He is vowing to appeal the ruling. We'll continue to follow this case because, honestly, we can't help ourselves. We can't look away. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb15', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb15', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } Democrats forecasting a Blue Wave of voters in November, we'll see. Some of them overtly say that illegal aliens are part of that wave. In the State of Georgia, Democratic gubernatorial candidate Stacey Abrams says the Blue Wave will include all segments of society, including "Those who are documented and undocumented". Illegal immigrants, of course, are not allowed to vote in federal elections. But Democrats increasingly are pushing back against that assumption. Will Jawando is the Democratic nominee for Montgomery County City Council in the State of Maryland, and he joins us tonight. Will, thanks a lot for coming on.

utterances.speaker: WILL JAWANDO, DEMOCRATIC NOMINEE FOR MONTGOMERY COUNTY CITY COUNCIL
utterances.sentences: Good to be here.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So, this seems like a bright red line that you would never want a foreign citizen voting in your election. Would you?

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: Yes. And they're not allowed to. And that's - and that's - next - not actually what Stacey was saying. I think it's a distraction to talk about that. Her point was the larger point that there's a lot of ways to be civically involved. I often say voting's the end of the civic process. Before that, you ask your Congressman for or your City Councilman for a sign on your street, you organize, you protest. The DREAMers are a perfect example, not citizens, but they've had tremendous political impact on both sides of the aisle. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb16', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb16', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But why would she want someone who's here illegally, who's not supposed to be here? You didn't welcome the person living here in violation of your laws--

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --taking services illegally, using a fake federal ID, which a 100 percent of them are, why would you want that person influencing your political process?

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: Well DREAMers have influenced it greatly.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No, not DREAMers - there are 22 million illegals--

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: But they're the same types of people--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No, not - not the same. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb17', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb17', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: --you're talking about here.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: There's a special legal designation for DREAMers, fair or not being upheld by a federal judge now. But the overwhelming majority are not DREAMers. There are 22 million illegals. That's the federal term for them. Why would you want them influencing anything about your country?

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: Well if you live here - well, first of all, undocumented, I'd like to call them undocumented individuals, they pay over $20 billion in federal taxes but receive no benefit--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well that's of course not - that's - that's not - not true at all- -

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: --no social security, no Medicare, no and they --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --and actually they - they receive billions in - in Medicare - they're - in Medicaid. And, of course, the overwhelming majority of the bursts that they have in this country are paid for by you and me, legal citizens. So, they take a lot. We educate their kids. They use our infrastructure. But the question is more a theoretical one. Why if someone is breaking your law, would that person have a right to influence, is a citizen of a foreign country, like the Russian hackers who hacked our - no, I'm serious. It's a foreigner who's not allowed to be here, why would that person-- if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: Everyone arrived--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --avail those benefits ?

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: --here at some point, even your ancestors, right?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: We --

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: And when they got here they got engaged in the - in the civic life of their community. They went down and figured out how to figure out how to have their community to be safe, how to get a driver's license, how to apply for a school--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But it was illegally for sure--

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: Yes. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I'm not making an argument against immigration--

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --at all. I'm just saying--

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: But and again, they're not voting. She wasn't saying that--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But is there a dis - no, but you're saying that--

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: --they should vote.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --they should have an influence on our election-- if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: They already do. It's a fact.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But why would - why would we want that--

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: Because anyone who lives here in the county that's--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --why - well I'd be horrified about this.

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: --contributing to - in the country that's contributing to our democracy has a right--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So what - so citizenship--

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: --to be heard. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --so what does citizenship do ?

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: That gives you right to vote. They don't have the right to vote--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But should - but they have every other right --

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: --but they can participate in the civic process --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --short of that. Even if they're here --

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: --well they're human beings.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --even if they're here illegally?

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: Even if they're here undocumented illegally, yes, people could participate--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: They have the right ?

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: --in the civic process.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So, do I have --

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: President Trump said that--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --wait--

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: --DREAMers can participate in a civic process.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: The DREAMers are a tiny--

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: No, they're the same thing.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --no, no, they're not at all the same thing. They are not here --

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: Are they not undocumented and illegal ?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --they're not here illegally because the--

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: Yes, they are.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --President Obama made them legal temporarily, as you know.

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: Right, right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But the 22 million are here illegally--

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: But before that they - they advocated to beget that status.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: And they shouldn't have--

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: They did not have that status.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --they shouldn't have gotten it. And for political reasons, the former President caved to their demands. My question is do I have this right to go to a foreign country and demand that they change their - the way they - they govern themselves?

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: Oh, people do it all the time.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Do I--

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: Americans are overseas advocating for all sorts of changes in--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Really? So--

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: --in repressive countries and nations across the world.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: And you think that's OK? If I show up in a country illegally, I just walk into Mexico and I say "I demand that you make accommodations for me," do you think there's - that's a little weird or no?

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: Not accommodations. What I'm saying is that--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well that--

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: --we're having an immigration debate in this country that's been going on for a long time. If you go back to President Reagan, he made a lot of people legal--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No OK but --

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: --all that stuff is happening.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --he - he - he made a lot of people legal. And it was a huge mistake, I think. I'm not here to fight for Republicans--

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: Well--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --I'm here to determine what the truth is. And if I go to a foreign country and they say, "You're not allowed to be here," and I say "Shut up racist, you have to listen to me. I demand you allow me to stay." Would you say--

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: But no one said that here.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --what do you mean no one said ?

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: You're saying it. No one has said that.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Are you joking?

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: No, no one's said that.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: We - we run tapes of illegal aliens all the time burning U.S. flags, carrying Mexican flags, calling anyone who opposes Americans --

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: There's plenty of Americans that burn U.S. flags too.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I - I agree. And I'm against it but they're citizens--

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: Right. Me too.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --it's their country. And it's not--

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: So, do you want to load everyone up and just ship them out to --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, well most of them, I think--

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: --South Africa or --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --I mean if they're here illegally--

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: --the DREAMers too or who--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well, no, I guess they have a right to stay.

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: --who are but - what's your criteria?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well the President said that these people have a right to stay. OK. And a federal judge has upheld that. I disagree. But that's the law.

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: The other law is that people who are not here legally have to leave. There are 22 million--

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: So, if we passed a pathway to citizenship like President Bush wanted to do, and we got--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I would oppose that but if it were the law, see I believe--

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: --we have it close you'd go along with it --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --in the law. You guys don't.

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: I - I believe in the law as well.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Then why wouldn't we deport everyone here illegally?

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: This - the - the lead-in to this story with Stacey Abrams as that saying that illegal immigrants should vote. She didn't say that. And that's what I'm talking about --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well no she --

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: --no one's saying that.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --that I think she was saying that but you're saying that illegal aliens have a right to influence our political process, and I'm saying we should be horrified by that prospect. Why wouldn't we be?

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: No, no, no, no, everyone started here as an illegal immigrant or immigrant of some or--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No, no, that's not true.

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: --of some--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: --some point.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I'm looking at my stage manager who grew up in another country and came here legally.

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: Well so did my dad. They came - he came over here--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Exactly. Exactly.

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: --even - even if you have people coming to this country when the Irish came off the boats, they weren't necessarily legal, you know, so people were not - that's the way this country was formed.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So we have no right to defend our borders because the Irish came?

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: No. Of course, we can defend them.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh, OK.

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: Of course we can defend them.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Thank you for that. I mean I wish we had more time. I think it's an interesting topic.

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: We'll come back.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: And I appreciate taking time out of your schedule to join us.

utterances.speaker: JAWANDO
utterances.sentences: Only citizens should vote though.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Amen. Hillary Clinton out again defending her husband after posing as a champion of women. How does that work? We'll find out from Camille Paglia. She was, by the way, Hillary, the leader of our incompetent ruling class, one of the reasons Trump got elected, one of the reasons she's on the cover of new book called Ship of Fools. You can get a copy almost anywhere. Stay tuned.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well just recently, Hillary Clinton said that Brett Kavanaugh could not be allowed on the Supreme Court. We had to believe his accuser, she said, even without evidence. But Clinton turns out to be one of the most self-aware politicians in this country, that's a high bar, so it wasn't too surprising that on Sunday she backtracked from this position. She told CBS that her own husband had no obligation to resign over the Monica Lewinsky scandal.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Some today have said he should have stepped down.

utterances.speaker: TONY DOKOUPIL, CBS NEWS
utterances.sentences: In retrospect, do you think Bill should have resigned in the wake of the Monica Lewinsky scandal?

utterances.speaker: HILLARY CLINTON, FORMER FIRST LADY OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: Absolutely not.

utterances.speaker: DOKOUPIL
utterances.sentences: It wasn't an abuse of power?

utterances.speaker: CLINTON
utterances.sentences: No, no.

utterances.speaker: DOKOUPIL
utterances.sentences: There are people who look at the incidents of the 90s and they say, "A president of the United States cannot have a consensual relationship with an intern. The power imbalance is too great."

utterances.speaker: CLINTON
utterances.sentences: Who was an adult, but let me ask you this, where is the investigation of the current incumbent?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well even the ladies of "The View" are not buying this line of argument. Instead, they ripped Hillary Clinton, believe it or not, for her evasive interview tactics. Here's a selection. JOY BEHAR, "THE VIEW": What she just did is exactly what the Republicans do.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BEHAR
utterances.sentences: They change the subject so that's why we never get anywhere in the discourse. ABBY HUNTSMAN, "THE VIEW": You know, you know you have a bad argument when your immediate response is, "Well, they were worse." Call it out for being wrong and for being bad for all those years. I just don't think she can have it bit - both ways.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes. MEGHAN MCCAIN, "THE VIEW": Juanita Broaddrick claims that--

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MCCAIN
utterances.sentences: --Hillary tried to intimidate her into silence. Kathleen Willey claims that Clintons tried to intimidate her into not telling the truth. She called Mona - Monica Lewinsky a narcissistic looney toon, Gennifer Flowers, some failed cabaret singer-- Democrats have got to move on from the Clintons.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Camille Paglia is an author, one of the country's best-known cultural critic. She has written extensively about Hillary Clinton for more than 20 years, among many other topics. Her latest book is titled Provocations, and Camille Paglia joins us tonight. We're honored to have you. Thank you very much for coming on. So--

utterances.speaker: CAMILLE PAGLIA, CULTURAL CRITIC
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --yes, Hillary Clinton is mentioned actually quite a bit in this book.

utterances.speaker: PAGLIA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But before I ask you broader questions about what's happening in this country, what's your reaction to her role in the - the kind of MeToo movement of right now?

utterances.speaker: PAGLIA
utterances.sentences: Well it's very ambiguous. I - I don't - I think that her - her history has been hypocritical. I was the only Democrat feminist to call for Bill Clinton's resignation, and I had voted for him twice and - and don't regret it. But it was a scandal that the - the squalor that he introduced into the people's house even this - all this was happening, the servicing of him by - by an intern in the White House offices.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes. No. It's a - it's a very good point and a good reminder. So what, as you, as someone who's written about sex and gender roles in our society for so long, for many decades, what do you make of the convulsion we're going through, particularly, of the MeToo movement?

utterances.speaker: PAGLIA
utterances.sentences: Well it's - it's great that attention is being paid to the women being - women being abused. I - in 1986, I was lobbying for moderate sexual harassment guidelines at my university in Philadelphia. But I think we've gone a bit too far here. I think that, you know, fundamental civil rights involving the presumption of - of innocence or they have to be considered, so what I'm - I - what I espouse as a feminist is that women themselves must take charge of their own interactions today with men. They must signal at the time that something is unacceptable. This waiting 10 years, 20 years, 30 years is - this is not a - not only not American, it's Stalinist.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But women were told again and again by people who claim to empower women are themselves powerless and can't, they can't say anything because they're so--

utterances.speaker: PAGLIA
utterances.sentences: Absolute nonsense.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --lacking in power. OK.

utterances.speaker: PAGLIA
utterances.sentences: Nonsense.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: PAGLIA
utterances.sentences: No. Working class women, yes, may be so dependent upon a job that they cannot protest. But there, as I have written, there's no excuse for well-educated, upper middle-class professional women to let offenses to their dignity go by. You must draw the line when it happens. It's absurd that you feel too powerless, you can't complain. These people that - women who - who say that are simply putting the career advantage over the larger question of - of feminist issues and the protection of women.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You - you've written so much about, I mean just be blunt, about sex for all these years, what do you make of seeing your, I guess, former allies on the Left strike an almost evangelical or Puritan position on these questions, a kind of bluenose outrage at sensual pleasure, at personal happiness telling you that, you know, you're not allowed to do this or do that, I mean what do you make of this?

utterances.speaker: PAGLIA
utterances.sentences: Well there has been a split within feminism since second-wave feminism was born in the late 1960s. The media has - have been extremely lazy and not pursuing this.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, right.

utterances.speaker: PAGLIA
utterances.sentences: I belong to the pro-sex, pro-pop culture wing of feminism. I - I favor the legalization of prostitution. I have defended pornography. I admire strip clubs etcetera, etcetera, so there's - there has been this argument for a very long time. My - my branch one in the 90s, thanks to Madonna suddenly bursting on the scene, but then Madonna has faded and lost all sense of her own trajectory, and I am astonished after the victory of the pro-sex wing that we're back to feminist Puritanism again of the Andrea Dworkin kind. We're talking about mental imbalance. We're talking about hysteria that has nothing whatever to do with women's rights. These are neurotics, OK, who are - who are talking about hatred of men, who are poisoning the culture, making it more difficult--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAGLIA
utterances.sentences: --for young women to reconcile with young men.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You may not agree with Camille - Camille Paglia if you're watching the show. But trust me, one of the more interesting people out there and an engaging writer, and this is her new book, Provocations, and they do indeed provoke. Camille Paglia, it's great to see you tonight. Thank you for that.

utterances.speaker: PAGLIA
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Party leaders won't admit it. But Democrats are laying the groundwork for impeaching the President should they take the majority in the House next month. Is that wise? That's next.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well leaders of the Democratic Party are trying very hard not to talk about it in public, but Democrats are, as a factual matter, on track to impeach the President if they retake the Congress in November. They retake the House which looks likely, to be honest, and they have no choice in that. The Democratic base is so amped up, hating Trump is the one thing that holds them together, that the vast majority of them think the President should be impeached. For what? Doesn't matter, being a bad guy. In November, if they take the House, they probably will have no choice but to go for impeachment whether they have a good reason for it or not. Everybody knows this. Richard Goodstein is an attorney, a former adviser to Bill and Hillary Clinton and he joins us tonight. Now Richard, let me just say, I'm pretty sure you're against impeachment, OK, because you - you were here for the whole Clinton impeachment, you saw how it hurt the Republicans. You don't like Trump but you also know there's no actual high crime or misdemeanor for which you could impeach him. It's insane. But you also know your base and you know that they're - they are insane. So how is the Democratic Party going to keep from being driven by its own lunatic voters if they take the House?

utterances.speaker: RICHARD GOODSTEIN, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST
utterances.sentences: Well just for the record, I actually think it's not just high crimes and misdemeanors, it's treason, bribery, high crime, I - I actually think that the - the--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --universe of things that we can go after but let's abstract for another day --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So having a press conference with Vladimir Putin could get you impeached?

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: I - I think if he knew about the fact that close family members were co - were consorting with the Russians to run the campaign, yes--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Consorting with the Russians--

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --that is but again, that's for - that's another discussion.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --OK.

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: The fact of the matter is the Democrats - the Democratic leaders are pushing off discussion of impeachment because they're going to win on healthcare, and on the issue of "Do you contain Trump or do - do you enable him?" And I think most people want to contain him. Look, the fact is in 2014, most Republicans wanted to impeach Obama and that didn't cause the Republican leaders to go after impeaching him then--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh, I remember that. That's when they were surrounding Democratic lawmakers in restaurants and pounding on the front doors of the Supreme Court and screaming like wild animals and shooting people with bear spray in the streets of Portland where the Republicans were do I'm - yes, it's all coming back to me. I mean come on, there's no comparison between the lunacy on display on the Left, it's a threat to you, as you know, and what the Republicans are up to like they can't control those people. They're not controlling them now.

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Yes. I - I would say there's no comparison to locking up babies in cages with anything that Barack Obama did. That's what infuriating - -

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Babies in cages?

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --people to surround people in restaurants. Look, here's what the Democrats are going to do if you--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: What are you talking about?

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --really want to know.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Babies are being put in cages?

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: On the Mexican border but again, another discussion. I think what's going to happen is there are going to be public hearings--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I missed that part, OK.

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --public hearings like Watergate on the Russian attack, on the emoluments, on obstruction of justice, on tax fraud, money laundering, bank fraud, oh and a series of things, I don't think they're going to be going after impeachment because I think politically they realize it couldn't clear the Senate, and they, frankly, rather have a weakened Trump to run against than--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Wait. So can I just ask you a sincere--

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --a mighty one --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --question? Do you really think after two years of talking about Russia, when Russia poses no actual threat to us, the threat is China and Google, I mean they're real threats, Russia's not in the running, you really think they're going to have hearings on Russia? You think that helps them to talk more about Russia and Vladimir Putin and treason? I mean, honestly, you think they would do that? That's so nuts.

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: I - I think Trump appointed officials at the top of our intelligence community, you've heard about this Pompeo fellow. Remember, he was - used to be Head of the CIA. He said that the Russians attacked the United States and pose a threat to us as did they--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I don't care what Pompeo says. Do you really think that we need more hearings on Russia? Russia, honestly--

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: I absolutely think, I think with --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --that a lot of voters would want that?

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --all these people that - I think all these people that testified behind closed doors in the House and even the Senate should like the Watergate hearings brought that's what's the public is going to know, what really happened. And I think the Mueller report, frankly, will lack that. It will lack kind of the face and the immediacy of what the public hearings would do. So yes, I do think --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So you're saying the Mueller, an independent investigation that extends beyond two years is not enough. We need more hearings about Russia. You really--

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Well--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --and you think the public's going to say, "Thank heaven. We elected the Democrats. I want to hear more about Russia?"

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You really think so?

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: I would be more sensitive to that charge - I would be more sensitive to the charge about how long Mueller's going on. If there was a single Republican that complained when Ken Starr went beyond year two, three, four, etcetera, so yes, I actually think the public is deserve - is owed a hearing--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --a public hearing and should know about --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: More Russia.

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --what happened. I don't think they're - they're not got - they haven't gotten that yet.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I know out there throughout the Fruited Plains, people are grateful that we're going to keep talking about Russia--

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: You got it. OK.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --into - into the next millennium. Richard, thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: GOODSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Let's - let's talk the day after the Mueller report comes out. How's that?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Russia. Well in other foreign news, Saudi Arabia's government is accused of murdering a journalist and critic. Now, they may say it was an accident. Mark Steyn weighs in on that next. Also, Washington permanent class needs to impeach Trump because they can't acknowledge that he was legitimately elected. If they did, then it would expose how badly they have run the country for the past three decades. It is detailed in a new book that you can buy wherever books are sold. It's on the screen.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well, as of right now, the Government of Saudi Arabia is denying any involvement in the disappearance and the likely murder of the Washington Post columnist, who disappeared after entering a Saudi consulate in Turkey to get a document. "We don't know what happened to him," they're saying. But tonight, the Saudis reportedly are considering admitting that the journalist was, in fact, killed. Trace Gallagher has more on this developing story. Hey, Trace.

utterances.speaker: TRACE GALLAGHER, FOX NEWS
utterances.sentences: Hey, Tucker. In fact, there are now multiple reports that Saudi government is putting together an explanation to acknowledge that Jamal Khashoggi was killed during an interrogation that went wrong, and that the real intent was to abduct Khashoggi and bring him back to Saudi Arabia. The goal for this new narrative is to absolve Crown Prince Mohammad Bin Salman of responsibility by giving him plausible deniability. In other words, saying the Crown Prince didn't order the killing. But analysts point out, for the past two weeks, Saudi Arabia has denied having anything to do with Khashoggi's disappearance even when there was video of Khashoggi entering the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul but then never leaving. Turkish authorities also reportedly have audio and video evidence that Khashoggi was killed inside the Consulate, though that information has not been released. And then there's the matter of two Saudi planes arriving in Turkey the day Khashoggi disappeared carrying 15 members of what many have described as a hit team. Those men were waiting at the Consulate for Khashoggi's arrival. And Turkish investigators believe they killed him, dismembered him, and took his body away. President Trump said a short time ago he is aware of reports that Saudi Arabia may claim Khashoggi's death was unintended though Mr. Trump could not confirm that statement. Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Trace Gallagher, thanks for that update.

utterances.speaker: GALLAGHER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Here to bring us more is Mark Steyn. So Mark, it's hard, call me naive, but it's hard for me to believe that a primitive desert theocracy that beheads its critics in public squares would hurt one of its critics who works at the Washington Post. Were you shocked by the story?

utterances.speaker: MARK STEYN, STEYNONLINE.COM
utterances.sentences: Well I think you may be doing them a bit of a disservice there, Tucker. I mean according to the Turks, they actually flew in an expert in bone sawing just before this man entered the Consulate and, as the Saudis are now preparing to say, was accidentally questioned to death, awfully so it could happen to anybody. You could wander into the Swedish consulate, it might happen to you. I mean that's - that's just the way it is. The--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: --the only - the only mystery here is why if the Turks who - who claim to have basically seen all this stuff going on in the hours beforehand, why they haven't actually released it? And there is actually a kind of Turkish Saudi feud that this particular reporter was very much on the Turkish side of. But other than that, you know, you're right. This is one of the most bloodthirsty regimes on earth. It's basically ISIS with diplomatic recognition. The only entertainment in Riyadh on a Friday is the beheadings in Chop Chop Square. And regardless of liberalization and all the rest of it, this is how they deal with their perceived enemy.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So I'm confused though about the media coverage of this. And, by the way, I - I think American journalists have a right to be upset that a guy who wrote for the Post was apparently dismembered in a Turk - in a Saudi Consulate. But the Saudis also may have had, and there's evidence they did, advanced knowledge of 9/11, and they funded madrasahs across the Islamic world that have dramatically increased the incidents of terrorism. No one ever says that but they're very upset about this.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Are we missing the larger story here, maybe?

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Yes, I - I think so. This particular reporter, in fact, before he became - before he arrived in America, he was very close to Prince Turki, who was the--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: --Saudi Intelligence Chief and, later, the Ambassador in London and Washington. My connection to Prince Turki is that he once said, "The arrogance of Mark Steyn knows no bounds," which I liked so much, I - I had it put as the endorsement on the front cover of my next book. But you mentioned 9/11. Prince Turki stepped down as Saudi Intelligence Chief 10 days before 9/11. This guy, Khashoggi, who's the nephew of the biggest and most celebrated Saudi arms dealer--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Of course.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: --of his generation, this guy Khashoggi, before he fell out with the Saudi Royal Family was Prince Turki's biggest buddy. There - this is one of those, you know, there were no real - he doesn't deserve--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh exactly.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: --to be chopped up in a consulate but there are no good guys in this story.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: That is such a good point. So quickly, with all the news today about Elizabeth Warren and her American Indian heritage, which rounds out to about 0 percent, we want to recall the time that we prepared one of the traditional recipes that Warren submitted to the cookbook--

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --Pow Wow Chow, very quickly, from our archives.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: This is not a DNA test. There's no 23 in here. We're not getting to the - to the--

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And it's a cold omelet--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --to the truth of this necessarily.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: --which is, again, very interesting--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But is it redolent of--

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: --idea.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --Native American culture? And I'm about to tell you--

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: And I can eat this?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes, go ahead--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK. I'm going to do that.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: --everything is good to go. Yes, definitely. You know, you let me know. I mean I don't, you know, I don't dabble too much with Native American cooking but I wouldn't - this is not would - what would come to mind immediately. But again, I'm not an expert.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Good.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: But it's good?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: If this is traditional Cherokee food, sign me, I can see why Elizabeth Warren would pretend to be a member of this tribe--

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Oh, really --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --definitely I liked that.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: The full Fauxcahontas cooking experience with recipe available online on our Facebook page. Take a look after the show. So Mark, really quick, were you won over by her DNA test?

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes. This is a no doubt traditional Oklahoma Cherokee crab recipe. It's in the state song, Oklahoma where the crab comes sweeping down the plain. It is in - it is in fact the Duke and Duchess of Windsor's favorite recipe from a Manhattan restaurant. And I--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: That's --

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: --love that about - I - there's a displaced Cherokee with an authentic Cherokee recipe, who didn't get in because according to Elizabeth Warren, the House of Windsor were one of the five tribes in her world. That's - that's where affirmative action - that's where affirmative action leads folks. The first Native American Head of State in America was King George the Third, if only we'd known.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Nobody beats Mark Steyn. That's always the lesson when you come on. Mark Steyn, thank you, great to see you.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Thanks a lot, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Elizabeth Warren's made-up Cherokee heritage helped her a lot at Harvard. Meanwhile, Asians are hurt by the discriminatory policies of that school. We'll talk about the lawsuit underway right now against Harvard. Stay tuned.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Harvard University going on trial right now for discrimination - racial discrimination. One group is suing the school saying that it systematically penalizes Asian applicants based on their race, and there's a whole lot of data to believe that is absolutely right. Vijay Ingam is the author of Almost Black: How I Got Into Medical School By Pretending that I'm Black, and he joins us tonight. Thanks so much for coming on. So, we've been laughing about this Elizabeth Warren story because it's obviously ludicrous. But the fact is she was helped, it seems clear, by claiming to be one race. Many others are hurt by this system though, which is not quite as funny. Tell us your reaction to what you've seen at Harvard?

utterances.speaker: VIJAY JOJO CHOKAL-INGAM, ALMOST BLACK AUTHOR
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, the scam that Harvard has pulled by hiding their racial discrimination beats posing as Black to get into Medical School any day.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CHOKAL-INGAM
utterances.sentences: OK? Harvard has used diversity as a justification for racial discrimination against Asian-Americans and White people. They reduced Asian-American enrollment in their class from 43 percent to 18 percent using discrimination. In fact, their own Internal Committee found evidence of discrimination, and, of course, they buried the report. Edward Blum, I spoke at a rally with Edward Blum, and Students for Fair Admissions, the Asian American Coalition for Education recently, and all of this was caught alike because of that. We can see the racism plain as simple in front of our eyes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But I'm confused. So why is this not one of the biggest stories in the country? The most famous university in the world, the oldest in America, the most prestigious has been caught red-handed discriminating on the basis of race, they're not even defending themselves and nobody covers it, why?

utterances.speaker: CHOKAL-INGAM
utterances.sentences: I - I can't speak for - for the - for the motivations of the media. But what I can say is that people - it's so hidden. They buried in such a way that only a Professional Admissions Consultant like myself can understand how complicated it is, their discrimination. It's plain and simple racism. But it's so carefully hidden behind words like personality trait and that. What is it? It's racism.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CHOKAL-INGAM
utterances.sentences: It's carefully hidden but it's racism.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: We only have, unfortunately, like 30 seconds left but I mean you said this. You're one of the bravest people I've seen on this topic.

utterances.speaker: CHOKAL-INGAM
utterances.sentences: Well I - I want to tell - I want to say something --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Have you taken a lot of gut for this?

utterances.speaker: CHOKAL-INGAM
utterances.sentences: I've taken a lot of gum. But I wanted to thank President Trump. He has been our greatest ally in our fight against racial discrimination. We have a conservative majority, an anti-affirmative action majority in the Supreme Court because of him. Because of President Trump, our issues are being brought before universities like this.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You know, you'd think that--

utterances.speaker: CHOKAL-INGAM
utterances.sentences: With his support --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --Liberals would be on your side because supposedly they were against it too, but they're not, it turns out. Vijay, thank you very much for coming on. I wish we had more time. It's great to see you.

utterances.speaker: CHOKAL-INGAM
utterances.sentences: Thanks.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: We're done for the night. We'll be back tomorrow, the show that's the sworn enemy of lying, pomposity, smugness, and groupthink. Good night from Washington. Sean Hannity, live from New York City right now. Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2018 CQ-Roll Call, Inc.
